hints_html: Remember to use the chain rule when differentiating \(h(x)\).
hints_latex: Remember to use the chain rule when differentiating $h(x)$.
hints_raw: Remember to use the chain rule when differentiating <math>h(x)</math>.
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Taking the derivative of \(h(x)\) and using the chain rule, we get:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h'(x) = \exp(f(x))f'(x) + 2f(x)f'(x)\end{aligned}\]

Substituting \(x = 1\) and using the given values of \(f(1)\) and \(f'(1)\) gives:

\[\begin{aligned} h'(1) &= \exp(f(1))f'(1) + 2f(1)f'(1)\\ &= 5\exp(2) + 2(2)(5)\\ &= 5e^{2} + 20\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, \({\color{blue}\displaystyle h'(1) = 5e^{2} +20}\).
sols_latex:
Taking the derivative of $h(x)$ and using the chain rule, we get:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle h'(x) = \exp(f(x))f'(x) + 2f(x)f'(x)
\end{align*} Substituting
$x = 1$ and using the given values of $f(1)$ and $f'(1)$ gives:

\begin{align*}
h'(1) &= \exp(f(1))f'(1) + 2f(1)f'(1)\\
&= 5\exp(2) + 2(2)(5)\\
&= 5e^{2} + 20
\end{align*} Therefore,
${\color{blue}\displaystyle h'(1) = 5e^{2} +20}$.
sols_raw:
Taking the derivative of <math>h(x)</math> and using the chain rule, we get:
:<math>
\displaystyle h'(x) = \exp(f(x))f'(x) + 2f(x)f'(x)
</math>
Substituting <math>x = 1</math> and using the given values of <math>f(1)</math> and <math>f'(1)</math> gives:
:<math>
\begin{align}
h'(1) &= \exp(f(1))f'(1) + 2f(1)f'(1)\\
&= 5\exp(2) + 2(2)(5)\\
&= 5e^{2} + 20
\end{align}
</math>
Therefore, <math>{\color{blue}\displaystyle h'(1) = 5e^{2} + 20}</math>.
